Question 1

Consider the following:

  • You have a random variable $X$, which is just a number (or a set of numbers) that is randomly chosen. In this case, $X$ is a string of n bits (where each bit is either 0 or 1), and each bit is chosen completely at random.
  • You also have another random variable $Y$, which is also an n-bit string. However, $Y$ doesn‚Äôt have to be random in the same way as $X$‚Äîit can follow any pattern. But $X$ and $Y$ are independent, meaning knowing $Y$ doesn‚Äôt tell us anything about $X$.
  • Now, we define a new random variable $Z$ by taking $X$ and $Y$ and combining them using something called the ‚Äùbitwise XOR operation‚Äù (written as $\oplus$). XOR works like this for each bit: ‚Äì If the two bits are the same (both 0 or both 1), the result is 0. ‚Äì If the two bits are different (one is 0 and the other is 1), the result is 1.

So, assuming we define $Z = X \oplus Y$, we apply this rule to each bit in the string separately.
